awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: CSinParallel: Experiential Learning of Parallel and Distributed  Computing Through Sight, Sound, and Touch
awd_abstract_narration:
Today's desktops, laptops, tablets, and smartphones all contain multiple core processing units. Many people today also use cloud computing services for online shopping, sharing photos, and other conveniences. Multicore computers and cloud computing services are both examples of parallel and distributed computing. Current computer science (CS) curriculum recommendations require every undergraduate CS student to learn about parallel and distributed computing (PDC). To help students master the complexities of PDC, this project will develop software and curricular materials that combine two strategies for making PDC topics tangible and accessible: inexpensive single-board computers and teaching materials that use sight, sound, and touch. By using these teaching materials to explore PDC topics, CS students will be able to see and hear parallel and distributed computations and touch the hardware performing those computations. The project team will also develop a free, interactive, online PDC textbook and a collection of "unplugged" exercises for learning PDC concepts without a computer.

The project will develop: 1) visual software and teaching materials that use the investigators' Thread-Safe Graphics Library so students can see parallel computations in real-time; 2) audial software and teaching materials for a new Thread-Safe Audial Library so students can hear abstract PDC concepts and computations; 3) manipulative learning systems constructed with inexpensive multi-core single-board computers so PDC systems are concrete and touchable; 4) "unplugged" activities that make PDC algorithms accessible to broad audiences; and 5) a free, interactive PDC textbook that will be deployed through a combination of client-side and cloud-based systems. These materials will be accessible through the CSinParallel.org website, a previously-funded NSF project (Awards 1226172; 1225739; 1225796). Broader impacts will include strengthening and diversifying the U.S. cyber-workforce, improving the PDC skills of CS instructors and students nationwide including those at minority-serving institutions, and diversifying the community of PDC educators through faculty-development workshops and new social-networking features on CSinParallel.org.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
About 20 years ago, computer chip manufacturers realized that the laws of physics would prevent them from continuing to produce more and more powerful CPU chips - which perform computer instructions - by simply adding more speed and more billions of transistors to single monolithic CPU circuits. Instead, ongoing increases in CPU power require that each CPU chip contain multiple cores (circuits for carrying out computer instructions) per chip. This CPU design strategy is called multicore parallelism.At about the same time, cloud computing arose, in which companies sell services that execute on their own computers, available over the Internet to other companies or individuals. Cloud computing is an example of distributed computing, in which multiple networked computers work together to achieve computational objectives.Our CSinParallel project began in 2009, dedicated to helping computer science (CS) undergraduates everywhere to learn the principles and practices of parallel and distributed computing (PDC), a field that includes multicore parallelism, cloud computing, and other forms of computing where multiple executions occur in parallel on individual and/or multiple networked computers. From the outset, CSinParallel produced modular PDC learning materials that other professors could use, emphasizing hands-on active learning for effectiveness, and offered regional training workshops for professors who may not already know PDC, so they could learn the principles hands-on by working through our materials themselves, then teach those same materials to their students.

Our theme in this third round of NSF funding is to use engagement of the senses to learn PDC better. A major focus of our project was deploying Raspberry Pi single-board computers in our learning materials. We developed inexpensive (about $125) Raspberry Pi kits for use in courses and our faculty workshops, which connect to a user's laptop to provide user interfaces with a Pi (Fig 1); and we developed online learning materials that explore multicore (shared memory) parallelism (featuring OpenMP) on the Pi hardware platform. The Pi units use our CSinParallel Pi operating system image, consisting of a standard version of Linux together with our CSinParallel system enhancements and code examples. We also developed the Self-Organizing Cluster (SOC) of Raspberry Pi units (about $250-300 for three Pi nodes), which uses commodity components together with networking and PDC software additions incorporated in our CSinParallel Pi operating system image, in order to quickly create and automatically configure a cluster consisting a network Raspberry Pi units or kits - without prior cluster computing experience on the part of students or faculty (Fig 2); and we developed online learning materials that explore distributed computing (with MPI), with programming in C language or Python. Besides these Raspberry Pi systems, the CSinParallel group also explored visualization and "hearing" of PDC algorithms using our TSGL and TSAL tools.We also drafted a free online textbook PDC for Beginners intended as a companion text for CS courses in the first two undergraduate years. For this book, we modified the Runestone interactive online textbook system to support many kinds of PDC computation, by creating a Runestone Backend PDC computation capability, making it possible for student readers to modify or write code examples for multicore parallelism, distributed computing, and GPU computing in various languages and computational libraries, and interactively submit their code and view the results within the Runestone interface (Fig 3).Intellectual Merit. We found that both students in courses and faculty workshop attendees who manually interact with our Pi-based learning tools can form better PDC mental models than those using PDC computing systems they can't see and touch, and they gained a better understanding of abstract concepts (such as race conditions and deadlock) with the help of these manipulative objects. Students and faculty also expressed high motivation to learn more PDC through hands-on interaction with these Raspberry Pi based systems. These findings mirror previous research on manipulatives in Mathematics Education. In addition, we found that teaching PDC algorithms with TSGL led to improved understanding of those algorithms compared with traditional learning approaches.

Broader impacts. Raspberry Pi systems are inexpensive, but our free PDC for Beginners book addresses two long standing entry barriers for learning PDC: the cost of PDC-capable hardware; and the challenge of installing and configuring PDC equipment and software. In order to make our online book and its PDC computations available to potentially thousands of simultaneous users, we have developed a prototype scalable Cloud Runestone Backend (which executes student PDC code using Kubernetes-managed containers), and have obtained grant funding and institutional support to integrate this cloud backend into our book's modified Runestone platform. We have also secured funding to operate the cloud-powered PDC for Beginners textbook free of charge for five years, which will enable students and faculty, with any socio-economic backgrounds at any institutions, to learn PDC with effective hands-on learning through actual PDC computations.
